Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Real Memory Test Is Here?: The Roles of Experimental Context and Participant Awareness on Retrieval-Induced Forgetting

POR.DRECONTENT:
In terms of retrieval-induced forgetting, participants who did not undergo an environmental change in context unsurprisingly showed normal robust retrieval-induced  forgetting effects. Participants who did experience an environemental context change, however, did not show significant retrieval induced forgetting.  The current study showed that participants undergoing a context change remembered significantly more items -- by a factor of about 10% -- than participants in the no-context change condition. Specifically, participants undergoing a context change were able to remember significantly more critical items than participants who did not undergo a context change. Recall for baseline items did not differ between the two groups (see attached graph).

Many studies evaluating context change often report that participants that undergo a context change actually recall less of the items compared to participants who remain in the same environmental context between study and test. The explanation behind these findings is generally that when we are studying materials, we are not merely coding the materials themselves, but we are also encoding aspects of our learning environment. Physical aspects of the environment can therefore facilitate retrieval as well, as they can also serve as cues during recall. When participants are removed from their learning environment during test, they can no longer use those cues, and recall of studied materials suffers as a consequence.

It is therefore puzzling that we obtained the opposite pattern of results in the current study. One possible explanation for this finding is that participants in the no-context change condition had more difficulty during retrieval than participants who changed rooms. The reason for the differences in retrieval difficulty at test may specifically be due to what is called a 'release of inhibition.'

One prevailing theory to explain retrieval-induced forgetting is called inhibition. It posits that when a participant is asked to recall an item from a category during the generation phase (FRUIT - B), previously items in memory are activated (e.g. Apple). However, none of the studied items are present in the generation task, so the studied items are not relevant. In an effort to make generation of the new item (Banana) easier, irrelevant items (such as Apple) are temporarily suppressed, or inhibited in memory.

One possible explanation for the current results, therefore, is that inhibition is released to some degree when participants experience a change in their environment. There may be some circumstances where it is not necessary to retain inhibition over irrelevant materials. In this study, participants memorized and generated items for roughly 15 minutes. Because this is a brief duration for the encoding of information, prolonged inhibition of the material, after a participant is removed from that context, may not be necessary.  This increased understanding of how inhibitiory functions affect memory is theoretically interesting, as it suggests that only contextually appropriate information is inhibited, and that at least one component of context can be the particular environment where information is learned.

Again, however, this pattern of results is extremely surprising given prior findings on context-change manipulations in studies of memory. It would be necessary to replicate these findings, ideally with a new set of materials, to ensure that it is a robust finding.
